slides.title: Customer Segmentation

content.headline: Stop Treating All Customers the Same

slides.narration: A first-time visitor isn't the same as a loyal regular. A big spender isn't the same as a bargain hunter. Segmentation lets you talk to each group in ways that resonate. Let's set it up.

slides.title: What You'll Learn
slides.narration: We'll cover why segmentation dramatically improves marketing effectiveness, how to create meaningful segments, using segments for targeted campaigns, and measuring which segments respond best.

slides.title: Step 1: Basic Segments

essential_segments.why: Different messages for acquisition vs retention

slides.narration: Start with essential segments. New versus returning customers need different messages—acquisition versus retention. Purchase recency: recent, lapsed, or at-risk customers. Spend level: VIPs deserve VIP treatment. Service type: send relevant offers, not everything to everyone.

slides.title: Step 2: Build Segments
slides.narration: Build segments in your system. Go to Contacts, then Segments. Click Create Segment. Set your conditions—you can combine with AND or OR logic. Name it descriptively so you remember what it is. Save and verify the count looks right.

slides.title: Step 3: Segment-Specific Campaigns
slides.narration: Create segment-specific campaigns. Lapsed customers over ninety days: we miss you plus special offer. VIP customers with high lifetime value: exclusive early access to new offerings. Service A customers: introduce complementary Service B. New customers in first thirty days: welcome sequence with education. Right message, right audience.

slides.title: Step 4: Measure and Refine
slides.narration: Measure segment performance. Track open rates, click rates, conversion rates, revenue generated, and unsubscribe rates by segment. When a segment underperforms, split it smaller—maybe 'lapsed' needs to be 'lapsed 90 days' versus 'lapsed 180 days' with different approaches.

slides.title: Pro Tips

tips: Test same offer to different segments

slides.narration: Segmentation pro tips. Start with four to six segments—expand as you learn. Segments can overlap; a customer might be VIP and also interested in Service A. Set up automatic rules so segments update as customer behavior changes. Test the same offer to different segments to see who responds best.

slides.title: Start Segmenting
slides.narration: Ready to stop treating all customers the same? Create your first segments now. Or browse segment ideas for your industry first. Targeted marketing starts with knowing who you're talking to.
